target: I bought this to remove tartar off my cats'teeth. Somewhere in the product information, or in my imagination, I thought this product was for Pet Teeth Not just for Dog Teeth. And though I am not a dyed in the wool dog lover, I wouldn't give this to a dog either. Here was my experience with this product:It came promptly. I still had some of my old tartar remover, so finished it off, then got a spanking clean cat bowl and put a few drops of the blue tartar remover in the bowl, then added clean water. Wow. The blue stuff foamed up in the bowl. Well, I had bottled water in the bowl, so I wanted to save some if possible. I poured half the blue foaming liquid out and refilled with water. Just a few bubbles appeared. So, since it was a clean bowl with bottled water, I put some of the water on my finger to taste it. No soapy taste, just a bit metallic. So I gave it to the cats. They drank a bit and wandered off. I estimate there were 2 drops in a pint of water.I also keep a bowl of water for them in the kitchen and it has NO tartar remover in it. Over a period of a week to 10 days, I noticed that the kitchen water had suddenly become a bigger hit than the water at the feeding station. Odd. I really wasn't paying too much attention UNTIL,I came in to refill the bowl at the feeding station and put in about a eighth of a teaspoon of the blue tartar remover.(So that is one eighth teaspoon in a pint of water.) It foamed up like mad. Suddenly, I realized the kitties were not drinking the blue foaming water, but were going into the kitchen to get pure water. I poured half the water out again, refilled the bowl at the feeding station and watched. Not a good video. Grey kitty smelled the light blue water, put his foot in it and walked to the kitchen. Brown Kitty woke up later and had some kibble. She drank about 2 laps of the treated water and headed for the kitchen.Cats will not eat or drink anything that is bad. If water is fresh, but in a puddle, yep they will drink it. If food has spoiled, no they will not eat it. I know they will drink anti freeze which kills them, but over all, they are quite discriminating in their tastes. I do not know exactly what turns them off about this blue foaming product, but they are having none of it. I ultimately threw my bottle away. I will not give it one star because I do not hate it, but I am certainly wary of it and will give no more to my kitties. This is definitely NOT a kitty product and I wouldn't give it to my dog either. Up to you and your dogs, but it surely does not Look right or pass the "Kitty says its OK" test. I vote against it.

We have two of these now, indoors only.They allow our cats access to litter boxes in the cellar w/o having to leave the cellar door ajar.We've also installed one in our bedroom door so it can be kept closed, too.(We keep the temperature lower....and a/c'ed in the summer!)Good price for a great option!

Easy to assemble, good size for my 1.5 inch Robo, no side door for escaping, cage bars are spaced tightly for safe keeping of mini animals, and very light to carry with a handle. Lots of possibilities for expansion with the fun-nel ports. My hamster loved it from the moment I put him in. I ended up buying another travel sized CritterTrail cage to put my new hamster in! Great cage and products!

This does take off a ton of fur.  My German Shepherd does not like it too much though.  She loves to be brushed regularly with other brushes, but this one not so much.  She does allow me to use it, but I can sense her discomfort, and she isn't as eager to be brushed when she sees me holding it.  I'm not sure if it takes off too much hair like others say, but I can see why they would think it, and I have to admit, that I am a bit concerned myself.

I'm so pleased with the Litter Genie.  It does everything it says it will do.  Since I have 4 cats I don't expect the bag refill to last as long.  It if lasts 3 or 4 weeks it will still be a great asset.  My pet sitter loves it too.
Great bed particularly for the price. After my dog ruptured her ACL I needed something soft and supportive for her to hang out on. All of my dogs & cat love this bed and tend to just pile on.

I have a small Cavalier and I bought this bag to travel with him for the first time (he's 8 mths).I liked the wheels on the bag because having a layover and lots of walking he was going to get too heavy.When I got the bag I used the same paper that came with the packaging to give it some shape (as it was folded, it had no shape and looked smaller than what it was) for a couple of days before traveling.My dog seemed pretty comfortable in it, he would scratch it a little every now and then (not enough if you ask me) by the time we got to our first stop he had broken the side he was scratching on (one of the sides with the clear-ish fabric. I had to figure out a way to keep him inside until we got to our destination. but this was really frustrating.Like I said he was in there scratching for 20 or so minutes total and then it was broken.I do like the fact that you can take the wheels off and my dog was overall pretty comfortable.Needs better quality. I had to go somewhere to get it back
when fishes are being treated for parasites or diseases, their best chance of survival is if they continually eat. this does attrack them to fish food.
Love the fact there isn't any stuffing in this toy.  My dogs haven't ripped it apart yet and still enjoy playing with it.

Love these for my power chewers! My 3 power chewers love these bones and they last about a month. All other bones get demolished within 48 hours. I have a Shar-Pei, a Coonhound, and a Brittainy Spaniel/Doberman/Border Collie Mix. These three dogs can chew through anything. The regular size is right for all of them, not too large and not so small that they cause a choking hazard. My little Bedlington Terrier likes these too. I got this shampoo from another website before and I love it. The smell is really nice and it always leave dog's fur very smooth. I am happy to find it on amazon.

Revised: I bought this cat food because of the wonderful low price and I enjoy the adorable cat on the commercials. My cats did eat this food, in fact they really enjoyed it. However, after reading the ingredients and doing some research, I completely regret purchasing it and feel just awful for feeding it to my cats. The first few ingredients are (which indicates the most prevalent ingredients) Water sufficient for processing, fish, poultry, meat by-products, wheat gluten. How disgusting is that?! "Fish" and "poultry"?? Not really sure how that can be counted as an ingredient...not "tuna" or "salmon" but "fish." Not "chicken" or "turkey" but "poultry." If it was a decent quality meat- they wouldn't feel the need to hide behind ambiguous terms. Then there's the by-product which is the stuff leftover once all the actual meat is harvested. We're talking beaks, chicken feet, eyeballs, even chicken poop! I would not recommend this product to anyone, for any reason, ever. It is an absolutely awful cat food. I suppose you get what you pay for. I think the only reason why it was cat-approved may be because it contains artificial flavors that taste good to cats and because I usually feed them dry food for dental reasons and wet food puts off much more of a scent for them to enjoy. I recommend to stay far away from Friskies, as it is simply a very low quality filler food. Even though the price is quite inexpensive, your cat will actually eat more than if you paid for a better quality food, because they will never feel full. Cats need to eat real, pure, meat, and there just isn't real identifiable meat in this food. When purchasing a cat (or dog) food, the most important thing to consider is the first 3 ingredients, just make sure those first three are decent ingredients that you would eat yourself. Now that I know what to look for, I usually buy my pets all natural, dry foods such as Natural Balance, Blue Buffalo, Halo or Wellness. All of those brands contain real, whole meats that I myself would eat, with no added fillers or ambiguous "meats".
I tried this and other products to clean the fur from furniture, upholstery and blankets at my shelter of cats, and it works, but not as good as other products.

This collar is effective for both of my 25-lb mixed breeds who bark at all of the neighbors when they're out in the yard. For the next few days after wearing the collar, barking continues to be reduced or stops, then they start up again and I have to put the collar back on them.However, when batteries ran out they were impossible to find except here at Amazon and the ones I ordered don't all work. I replaced the battery in both collars and only one works - I'll have to start going through the rest of the 10-pack to see if the others work better.If the replacement batteries were easier to find and always worked, this collar would be ideal.

The product works wonderfully picking up poop large & small and emptying "it" into a plastic grocery bag, quickly and efficiently.

I received a used toy! It was scratched, cracked and very obviously far from being new. I actually don't know if my cats would have enjoyed the toy, or not. And my bird loves it too.  It is one of the best maintenance bird diets out there.  Will continue to buy it if I can get it shipped for free.

I have a male cat that has been harassing the females. I put one diffuser upstairs and one downstairs. Things have improved a lot. The chasing has subsided almost totally. Occasionally there is a little swatting and hissing, but the difference is amazing. I highly recommend this product.

My dogs love greenies. I ordered these trying to save money instead of the Bright Bites that I had been getting. I think the Bright Bites might do a better job of cleaning the tarter off of their teeth though, and my dogs also love those. I will observe their teeth for a while on these more economical teeth cleaners and edit later if I think that it is indeed true that the Bright Bites do a better job of cleaning their teeth. They did have a better price online of some of the Bright Bites, but did not see the better deal as of late, so ordered these trying to save some money, about 1/3 the price of Bright Bites at the current price. We do brush their teeth every night and then give them these as a &#34,bribe&#34, for letting us brush their teeth. They are not crazy about getting their teeth brushed, but will submit to it because they know they are immediately getting a treat after having their teeth brushed. Just like little kids, my little dog girls!

I recently looked for supplements for my dog who has autoimmune arthropathy and came across this product and saw the good reviews. I decided to try it and am so glad I did. I had been using it for my dog for about six weeks now. My dog is more active and less withdrawn now and I didn't have to give her Rimadyl for at least 3 weeks (considering I was giving it twice a day at some point). How do I know this supplement works? I don't know. But what I do know is the difference I've seen in my dog before and after I put her on this supplement. I give it to her slowly as she lick the tip of the syringe. And please remember to REFRIGERATE just as an added precaution. I've forgotten twice to refrigerate right after using it but luckily, I realized it before it got warm so I really didn't worry about it.
I am trying to train my dog and needed a longer lead for some of the procedures and this was ideal for what I was doing.

it's bigger than his previous two hide-a-squirrels, so it is easier for him to get anything and everything out of it.Careful though, folks, my dog has a ball breaking the plastic inside the bottom of the toy into teeny tiny shards. When that happens, I have to cut open the bottom and pry out the pieces, which are VERY DANGEROUS if not removed and your dog gets at them.So if your dog is a tough chewer, as mine is, this toy will last quite a good while. Just be sure to extract the plastic shards (not a smart choice on the part of the manufacturer) after they are sliced and diced by your dog.

My elderly long hair Birman can no longer groom because of arthritis so I've been brushing and combing out his tangles for about a year.  I was using a flea comb which needed to be replaced. It's cute and the batteries last a while, and unless the dog has really dense fur it also helps give a beacon in the dark, which I thought was really cool (not what it was designed for, but I thought it was an extra plus).There's a red light that is motion activated to show you it's charged. I think this holds its charge pretty well.Things I've discovered through other dog owners since I've started using this, though: some people seem to have the misconception that this is going to train/stop your dog. It's not. It interrupts your dog from what he or she is doing, but you're still the one who has to provide the discipline. It'll interrupt your dog so you can get his or her attention, so you still have to reinforce the right behavior -jump in as soon as you've interrupted the dog with this.  This isn't a dog trainer, it just provides a little extra help.The other major concern I hear from other dog owners is that this thing might &#34,hurt&#34, their dog. Pfft. Yes, I strapped it to the inside of my elbow (yes, it's a sensitive spot), and gave it a couple pushes of the button.I learned a few things having tried this on myself:The first setting is basically a vibrate setting. If you ever played the Xbox, it's basically like your controller vibrating. The two metal knobs intensifies that a little bit -it'll scare your dog (heck, it gave me a start!), but it in no way hurts.  This will get your dog to go, &#34,OMGWTF!?&#34, for a split second, then you get your dogs attention and do what you have to.My dog adjusts very quickly and was able to start ignoring the first setting after a while.The second setting (the &#34,L&#34, button) is a shock. Don't worry about pushing the button or holding it down -this thing almost has cool down time built into it -it buzzes the dog (or you, if you're like me and want to tie this to yourself and try it out) for a fraction of a second, but doesn't keep doing it even if you hold the button down and you can't push the button fast enough for it to work like an electrocution device (but please, please don't take that as a challenge). So, this won't hurt your animal because it's not electrocuting your pet. If your pet adjusted to the vibrate setting like mine did, move on to this one. Again, buzz him, but jump in and reinforce the behavior you DO want. This only helps interrupt the animal from what he's doing, if you don't get in his space as soon as you can, his attention will go right back to what he was working on.The third setting -I'm assuming the &#34,H&#34, stands for high -doesn't actually feel any different than the &#34,L.&#34,  And yes, yours truly tried more than once to test the &#34,difference&#34, but couldn't feel one. After 4 shocks my forearm did feel kind of numb for the next 5 minutes, but this is not going to cause injury to a dog because, again, it's a small zap that lasts for a fraction of a second not electrocution (constant current). I know it's strange I have to reiterate that, but I've spoken to a handful of very concerned pet owners who believe this will actually fry your pet if you hold down or continuously press the button -that's not what this does (and hopefully not what any training aid is ever designed to do).That being said, if the &#34,L&#34, setting isn't dissuading your dog from what he or she is doing, the &#34,H&#34, setting isn't going to make a difference.
Really like the quality of this pad which I got for my puppy.  It has held up after numerous washing & dryings.

This little cup/bowl folds flat and can be easily slipped into a handbag, in the seat back pocket and even clipped to a bag or strap with the carabiner it comes with.  The bowl is sturdy enough when popped open and stays open securely at each fold/step.It can go in the dishwasher and is easy to clean. No more smelly hard to clean fabric bowls.  This is great for dogs who refuse to drink out of dark containers.One note of caution: if you have a dog that likes to splash in its water bowl, you may find that it may collapse the bowl spilling water all over the floor or even learn (& like!) how to collapse it (great! a new toy!).UPDATE: FEB 2011We are still using this cup daily since buying it in the summer of 2008 and so far it looks as new as the day we bought it. There is no visible wear. Excellent product!

I keep encouraging my dog that she can figure it out...but just between us humans I think it might be too hard. If I hold it and she pulls the rope, she can do it. But without hands to hold the bottle upside down, I don't really get how a dog could do it. She was really frustrated and stressed about the whole ordeal.My boy dog wasn't so stressed, and very determined. He's not quite as bright as my girl...but he sure had the heart for it! I doubt he'll get it either.I just got it today so I'll give it more time but I just don't think it's feasible when all you've got to work with is paws and teeth.That being said, they liked using it with me holding it, hence the three stars. We have 4 dogs. We own 11 crates. 1 set upstairs. 1 set downstairs. A set to keep at our parents' house.We love Midwest crates/products. They have held up very well.I needed another crate for our latest furry addition.I purchased this one because it appeared to be the exact same model that we had purchased previously.When it arrived, however, it was apparent that it had been redesigned. Might not meet everyones.

No longer do the other dogs in the neighborhood make fun of him and leave bottles of selsun blue in his food bowl. He's a very happy dog now and he seems to notice it too, because he isn't scratching or rubbing against things as much as before.

My Cavalier King Charles Spaniel loves his Orka Flyer! He loves to chew, and he's had this toy for almost a year -- which we call &#34,the Blue,&#34, and he hasn't torn it yet.  Charley chewed through a hard plastic frisbee within an hour.I love that &#34,the Blue&#34, is soft and flexible and easy of Charley's teeth and gums, I can't see that a hard plastic frisbee would be as gentle.  I fold the blue and use it to speak to Charley (like a hand puppet). He's learned to do that, too!  We play fetch in the house with the Blue -- we call all Charley's Orka toys &#34,the Blue,&#34, and Charley knows the difference between his Orka toys and his other toys.Charley has several Orka toys and most of them have held up under Charley the Chewer!

Bought after search for quality food fot catz with renal issues as ours refused to eat the prescription foods from vet's. There are lots of bowls out there that will circulate water in a pet's bowl. This is something that is more critical to a cat than to a dog because cats sometimes don't drink enough to prevent renal problems, but let's face it: Something good to drink is good for any mammal.There are a few problems with this device as a solution.1. I found it didn't stick flat to the bottom of the bowl very well. Most bowls have curved surfaces, and it seemed that no matter how I placed it, at least one suction cup didn't grip.2. If it's totally submerged, you really don't get the effect of rippling water that makes it more enticing to your pet, nor do you get any aeration, which should be part of a filtration system. You could put less water in a bowl so it wouldn't be submerged, but you'd need a very wide, shallow bowl. And then you're going to have evaporation issues.3. The filter is pretty darn small. Put this into regular service, and you'll be replacing a lot of filters, putting an end to any savings over the water circulating bowls like the Drinkwell or Petmate models.I wanted to like a water circulator for a pet that is less expensive than the fancy systems out there, but in this case, I don't think you even get what you pay for it. This might be better for a goldfish bowl, or something like that. And I can't help but imagine that a big, playful dog might even just snatch this thing out of the water like it was a chew toy!Another advantage a real fountain-type bowl system is that the power cord for the pump can be better hidden out of the way of curious pets. While it's only low-voltage, you still don't want your pet biting into the cord that's draped-over the edge of their water bowl.All in all, I'm glad this was a free model for review, and not something I spent good money on.

I have two of these (in green), each affixed to the front of my two Husky's Red Dingo Dog Harnesses, Large, Green. Great for visibility where we walk... amongst plenty of traffic, cyclists and other pedestrians. Brightness is great and I have had no issues with malfunctions or premature shut-offs as suggested by other reviews. So far, so good. Very happy.

The silver wooden slats slid up and down the legs. I had to glue them down to stay put (to look like the picture). Didn't feel like going through the hassle of a return for something so minor, but pretty shoddy nonetheless.

I didn't even know I NEEDED one of these till I got one. And I'll never do without it again. We have a 14 pound Egyptian Mau who, even for a cat, is a totally obsessive clean-nik.  He will remind me every other evening if I have been so neglectful as to have not thoroughly cleaned his litter box.  Even though he has a large Booda Dome like thisBooda Dome Cleanstep Cat Box, Titaniumall to himself, he wants it kept in perfectly raked, pristine condition.Being a servile underling to our lord and master, I was using plastic grocery bags to accomplish this, till I got the Litter Genie.  Here's what I like about it:1. It works something like an old-fashioned diaper pail, sitting ever-ready by the litter box.  When I need to use it, it's there.2. You "load" the Litter Genie by placing a plastic ring filled with double-layered bags inside the top.  By the second time you do this, you'll know exactly how.  I've only had to refill it once in the 3 months I've been using it (I empty once a week, on "garbage night").3. The double-walled bags REALLY make a difference in odor control.  No wafting odors, no ammonia smell.4. The opening at the top of the Litter Genie is a nice size & much easier to "hit" with a scoopful of litter than trying to hold a grocery bag open with one hand.5. Scoop the used litter into the top of the Litter Genie.  Then, slide out a little bar & the litter falls down into the bottom of the Litter Genie (into the bottom of your double-walled bag).  Push the bar back in & odors are sealed away.  Really.  The bar itself never touches the used litter, it's "lined" by the double-walled bag.6. On garbage night, I simply open up the Litter Genie, position the top of the used part of the bag into a built-in bag cutter, tie a knot, & throw it away.7. To deploy a fresh bag, just pull out about 8 or 10 more inches of the bag material, tie a knot in the bottom of it, close the lid & you're loaded and ready to go.  It's easier than it sounds : )8. The Litter Genie has a scoop holder (installed on the left or right side, your choice) AND its own scoop.9. The rounded corners of the outside make this an unobtrusive part of the room, it's not "clunky" looking at all.10. The Cat is Happy!Refills are a little on the expensive side, but worth it, in my book.  If you have family members with allergies (I do!), keeping the litter box as clean as possible can help quite a bit.  I also use a litter mat like this to help contain/reduce litter dust:Pruven P LTM 1824 T 18 by 24-Inch Litter Trap Mat,Tan. Highly recommended, one of my favorite finds of the year!

Only thing is we found we had to put half his kibble in and let him work on that for 20 minutes.  Then we put in the rest.  This is just due to the amount that ideally fits in at one time.  You can put all of it in at once.  But that actually makes it easier for him to eat and finishes faster. I have a medium-sized rabbit in a large dog crate.  This little box comes with two plastic attachments that screw down between cage bars.  My dog crate bars were spaced too far apart to fit these attachments, but I just bent the bars with a pair of pliers wrapped in a rag.  Alternatively, I could have constructed a plate out of wood that would have had the same result.  This litter box fits nicely in the corner, and the rabbit uses it exclusively until it is full.  If I don't clean it in time, he will move on to blankets and stuff.  At first, I was putting the paper litter on top of the bars, but the rabbit would dig them out.  Then I started filling the bottom under the bars, and that kept the urine smell down until I could change the litter, but the crottel would pile up on top.  After experiencing both methods, I have decided that the best thing is to put four packed cups of paper litter in the bottom, which fills the bottom a third of the way up.  Then the urine is absorbed into the litter, and the crottel falls into the container.  The rabbit seems to like it, and I do is well.  Overall, it is a simple and efficient design, and if I ever have additional small animals in the future, I would buy this product again.

PLEASE read the first few main ingredients before buying the product. Do not look at how fancy the wordings look but look at the actual ingredients that your cats will eat. Most of these food contain-1 - Chicken By-Product Meal -- "dry, ground, rendered clean parts of the chicken carcass."2 - Whole Grain Corn -- grains = high carbs = fat.3 - Animal Fat (preserved with Mixed Tocopherols and Citric Acid) -- a tocopherol is pretty much a form of vitamin E.4 - Corn Gluten Meal -- that's a protein corn by-product, it's a little deficient in lysine, so it shouldn't be the only protein source, which it isn't. (Yes, your pet can digest it just fine).5 - Brewers Rice -- another by-product, leftovers from the milling process.Please consider Grain-fee food for your cat if you want it to live a longer life because grain-free obviously doesn't contain grains, leftover meats, and the price is almost the same as these cheap 'craps'.

My dogs have always been fed a higher quality food so when they stopped eating their expensive food, I was panicked until I found this food. My boxspring/mattress/frame make my bed much higher then it use to be back in the day, I needed something to allow my pups(Chorkies) to get off the bed without having to jump from that hieght if they needed to. After much research on similiar products, Pet Gear III seemed to be the most purchased and enjoyed by dog owners. Yes I read there were difficulties in assembly and dogs not wanting to use it but I took the chance.1)The product is very sturdy and would trust my 90lb dog to use it.2)The stairs are wide which allows for a small breed puppy to come down one stair at a time and allowing his whole body to fit on the stair itself before taking the next stair down. There is a tilt to the stairs which a pup may feel is wierd but mine got over this real fast.3)Training, yes this could be an issue for some and one puppy went up and down it like it was nothing, my other puppy would not come back up the stairs. I felt as long as my puppies would go down the stairs they could bark to be brought back up on the bed, the safety issue was getting down off the bed not getting back up. She finally came up herself when one day her brother and I were up on the bed having fun and figured out I was not coming to pick her up.4)I blocked the one side of the stairs with a desk chair so that they would feel less intimidated by openess of the stairs since there are no sides which could make a stair using dog reluctant.(remember most stairs have a side since they are part of a wall)5)The best way to train a puppy to use stairs, is you do not start at the top(Lay at the top yourself and look down), you start at the bottom and get them to come down that first single stair then you slowly travel upward. I do not use treats for this, just leave them on that bottom stairs and gently call and slowly walk away, they are not going to want to stay there and miss all the action. If you have to play with a toy in the hall to get them interested in you and off the issue of the scary stair then do it. When you get to a high part you stay below them on the lower stairs to make sure they do not attempt to rush down the stairs possible injuring themselves(esp for people with hardwood stairs) and I always have a rug at the bottom with a non-skid bottom. Going up stairs is always easier then coming down..6)I would recommend these stairs, they are a life saver for my pups in preventing injury and future joint problems.

I have an Australian Cattle Dog who, like most ACD's, tends to fixate on things . . . in the case of toys, this means destroying them as quickly and as thoroughly as possible (and then looking disconsolate because he has no toy). When I first put this down for him (with one of the everlast treats it came with), he wasn't particularly interested (though he did get anxious when the cats went near it, so clearly it was on his mind). But eventually he got into it. He worked the treat out pretty quickly and ate it with gusto. So I moved on to treats on the inside (a little jerky and some liver biscotti), it doesn't take him long to get them out, but he sure enjoys it. He's also getting a kick out of playing with it and chewing on it even now that it's empty. So far it's holding up, but I worry about those little flaps for treat entry, I can't imagine they're long for this world with his obsessive chewing. Frankly, I don't expect it to "everlast" -- but he's so happy in the meantime that I'm okay with it.

We have 3 Maine Coon cats who have always loved their jumbo-sized Booda dome litter boxes (the kind with the internal ramp).  They are so good at being 'urinally responsible', and this ramp fits nicely into those exit areas.  It seems counter-intuitive that the mat slants downwards towards the box, but the litter tracked out is far less than the flat mats we'd bought elsewhere.  It takes some quick carefulness to lift up the box and dump the excess litter into the box while scooping or changing it out, but I felt that this is doing a great job keeping the daily mess off of the rest of the floor.

My cat likes sleeping in high places, so I thought she might like this product.  After adopting a new dog recently, I wanted somewhere for her to be able to go that was safely out of the way from the pup.  My cat likes to hang out in the office with me and my husband when we are both online, but there aren't too many hiding places for her there.  We thought this product would allow her an escape, whilst still enabling her to be in the room with us and feel safe from the puppy.My husband assembled this product within about 30 minutes.  His only complaint was that he'd have liked more detailed (written) instructions instead of just the images.  But once we got the base set up, this product turned out to be very easy and quick to put together.It is very sturdy, and I was impressed by how good it looks.  It doesn't look like too much of an eyesore in the corner of the room, for which I am glad.  I'm not too sure yet what my cat thinks to it - we've caught her rubbing her face against the platforms and even grooming herself whilst sat on the higher platorms, but she still prefers to sleep in the closet of the spare room!  I think she does like it , but it is far from her favorite place to hang out.  Maybe she'll warm to it in time.

I bought this in November 2012. It worked fine and had zero problems with it. Never had it on while I was cleaning and always had it above the minimum line. Kept water at the right temperature if I turned it up a little bit more on the dial.Here's what instantly gave this a 1 out of 5...I came home from work today and noticed the temperature was below what I keep it at. The green light is on, but obviously it's wrong. I go to check it out and the second I put my hand in the water I get an instant shock. I quickly unplug the heater, Pull it out, and grab my turtle out of the water. He was swimming around at the time. To make sure it was the heater and not the socket, I plug it into a different outlet and test the water. It drew an electric charge. This is going right in the garbage. I'm pissed off that my pet was in danger this way. He seems to be doing ok and hopefully so. I've never had a heater give off electricity in a tank. Usually, it just stops working. I already contacted Aqueon and waiting to hear back. I WILL NOT be buying from them again!
Easy for the dog to grab in the water, floats and is highly visible. My pup would go after this daily if I'd toss it for her.

I have had this little cage for a couple of years, and it has actually weathered all kinds of storms.
